bibl.title: Nag al-Hagar. A Fortress with a Palace of the Late Roman Empire. Second Preliminary Report.
bibl.note: This fortress is probably the residence of the praeses of Thebaid. Through the presence of the Emperor Diocletian (298) the place took the highly symbolic name Praesentia. It was one of the posts for the redistribution of the armed forces during the withdrawal from the Dodecaschoenus and the establishment of the frontier at Philae. - Pp. 203-204: The treasure of coins (77 coins, early IVth cent. A.D.).
bibl.seg: ABDEL WARETH Usama and Pierre ZIGNANI, Nag al-Hagar. A Fortress with a Palace of the Late Roman Empire. Second Preliminary Report.
BIFAO 92 (1992) pp. 185-210, 4 figg., 1 plan d√©pl. et pll. 23-34.

This fortress is probably the residence of the praeses of Thebaid. Through the presence of the Emperor Diocletian (298) the place took the highly symbolic name Praesentia. It was one of the posts for the redistribution of the armed forces during the withdrawal from the Dodecaschoenus and the establishment of the frontier at Philae. - Pp. 203-204: The treasure of coins (77 coins, early IVth cent. A.D.).
